sentence.text: Auriculocondylar syndrome, mainly characterized by micrognathia, small mandibular condyle, and question protein phosphorylation prolyl-tRNA aminoacylation, is a rare disease segregating in an autosomal dominant pattern in the majority of the families reported in the literature.

In order to address these questions, we searched for alterations in inositol trisphosphate biosynthetic process, adenylate cyclase-inhibiting G protein-coupled receptor signaling pathway, and negative regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II in patients with typical Auriculocondylar syndrome (n = 3), Pierre Robin sequence-plus (n = 3), micrognathia with additional craniofacial malformations (n = 4), or non-specific auricular dysplasia (n = 1), which could represent subtypes of Auriculocondylar syndrome.

entity.text: adenylate cyclase-inhibiting G protein-coupled receptor signaling pathway
negative regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II
